posts.name: Justin| Alum|FRC 3035
posts.cooked: Title. What are some laptops your team use for comp? We are looking for a new one for our team.

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: Well our laptops have terrible battery life so that is a consideration to keep

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: Our school gave us some lenovo thinkpads, I’m not exactly sure the model but they worked pretty well for us. My dream driver station laptop was a framework 13 but you don’t need to be that fancy.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
We have some 4-6 year old Dell 7420 and 7430s. We use the 7430s for programming and 7420s for drive and pit (because they’re ever so slightly slower).

The compute power needed for drive is pretty close to zero.

posts.name: Rob Madison
posts.cooked: We have a Dell Latitude 14 that was donated & a Dell Inspiron 15-3520 that I bought the team last year.

Get a business-class laptop, so the likes of Lenovo ThinkPads and Dell Latitudes. They’re generally the most reliable and have the best build quality. It doesn’t have to be a new one, you can get ones from a few generations ago for pretty cheap and they still preform well enough. Look for a laptop with an integrated ethernet port so you don’t have issues with a dongle, and preferably at least 2 USB-A ports to connect to controllers.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Second this!

If by chance you don’t get onboard Ethernet (which is getting less common), please be sure to get whatever USB to Ethernet adapter you plan on using sorted out and tested before your first event.

We’d done all our testing on wifi and rolled up to the field for our Week 0 without drivers for the Ethernet adapter. Excellent FTA support got us sorted out, but it was stress we could have avoided.

we started using a Framework 13 this season which has served us pretty well. it’s definitely pricier, but it’s a great laptop and it’s nice having custom ports (although the ethernet card is kind of chunky and somewhat prone to breaking).

also if it’s within your team’s means, it’s nice to have a computer dedicated to driving so you can debloat it + otherwise keep it a bit more sanitized

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
Some general thoughts

Look at the WPI Lib documentation around the requirements Driver Station Best Practices — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

An actual ethernet port , you’d be amazed that many machines these days don’t come with that.

Room for multiple devices / controllers

Decent battery life for those competition days so you may only need to charge it once

link_counts.title: Driver Station Best Practices — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Ashton A
posts.cooked:
This is mostly personal opinions, so take these with a grain of salt. From my most preferred to least preferred:

Framework FTW. Definitely a more pricey option overall, but you can’t go wrong with the repairability and option for a full sized Ethernet port.

Some Lenovo ThinkPad. Some recent 16 inch ThinkPads still have full-sized Ethernet ports when I checked a while ago, and were basically the only brand-new modern laptops I could find with full-sized Ethernet. Some 14 inch models include a hinged Ethernet port.

HP’s business (ProBook/EliteBook) line. This one probably isn’t the most popular, but I’ve been using a ProBook 445 G9 as a driver station and it’s been great. As far as I know, the ProBook 4xx and EliteBook 6xx are the only models that still have Ethernet ports, and they are unfortunately hinged (I’m pretty sure mine is starting to fail, but the piece that fails can be replaced if you desire). This is probably swappable with Dell IMO, but I have more personal experience with the HP lineup and it’s gone pretty well for me.

Dell’s business line. My main issue with these are the only two Precision lines that have had Ethernet for the past few years is the 3000/5000 series, and the 3000 series feels extremely cheap and the 5000 just seems to be a slightly better 3000 series. I took a look, and saw that Dell’s new Pro Plus/Max line does have the option to spec a Ethernet port, and those two models are the replacement for the 5000/7000, so those might be worth looking into.

Don’t think about any standard consumer laptops, in my opinion.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: We use Lenovo X1 Carbons. IMO they’re the workhorse laptop of American corporations, and they’re really robust as long as you uninstall all the Windows 11 bloat.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: For the same price range you can pick up a T Series ThinkPad with a full size ethernet port.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.cooked: Yeah, I agree. I’ve been using X1 Carbons for 5+ years; for personal use they’re amazing, especially when you have to walk around with them a lot, as they are incredibly lightweight, but I don’t think any of the things you get by paying more for them over the T or P series ThinkPads are really worth it for team use.

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked:
pigrammer:

T or P series ThinkPads are really worth it for team use.

Also, you can get AMD CPUs with the T & P series, which IMO are much better than Intel.

superdude311:

uninstall all the Windows 11 bloat

aspen:

debloat it

Debloating ends up causing more issues down the line and is completely unnecessary these days.

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked:
We use some model of dell notebook. im going to be honest i have no idea what the model is, but its a very simple one.

Apart from questionable battery life due to age, the one thing i wish it had was an ethernet port built in as well as USB A connections so we could directly connect controllers and network to it without daisy chaining hubs which can cause its own issues

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked:
USED Lenovo Thinkpad or Dell Latitude - as drivestation, you don’t need much processing power at all.  Anything that is ‘new’ enough to run Windows 11 should be fine (you’ll get Win 11 pro as those are usually standard OS for business class laptops - don’t stick with Windows 10, EOL is 10/25 and although you can keep it running it’s going to be a pain to try to keep it long term.  Bring a spare as backup laptop just in case someone drops the main one.  More and more laptops no longer comes with USB-A or Separated Ethernet port.  So plan on getting 2x external ones (and make sure they both works before hand).

Wed or Thurs before comp, run Windows Update and then do a full reboot and test the DS ’s.  MS Update come out on Tuesday night.  Then Disable Update before your comp.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: think outside of the box from time to time

posts.custom_user_title: think outside of the box from time to time

posts.name: Andrew Jahng
posts.cooked: We used to use our school-issued Lenovo 300e Chromebook Gen 3, but we got new Lenovo 300e Chromebook Gen 4 this year. Personally, I didn’t ever run out of batteries, but it was pretty close a few times (ended the first day of SDR at 3% if I remember correctly).

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: Whatever you by, use a USB hub and never unplug it. Laptop ports die and are almost impossible to fix. We’ve had reasonably good laptops become unusable because of port death.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
The answer is Dell Latitudes off eBay.  We’ve got a mix of 5410, 5420, 5520, and one 7490. Here’s the code:

First digit: series. 3 is basic, 5 is the sweet spot, 7 is thin and light.

Second digit is the second digit of the screen size. 4 is 14”, 5 is 15”, etc.

Third digit is the series.  The last Latitudes were 5.  But older ones did loop around, so sanity check your searches.

Fourth digit is usually 0, but other numbers indicate variants of the line (say, AMD instead of Intel).

Or if you’re bougie, the Dell Pro [screensize] Plus is a good stout laptop that’ll last you years. That replaced the Latitude line in Dell’s (no-less-mystifying) product naming scheme.

Zook:

Whatever you by, use a USB hub and never unplug it. Laptop ports die and are almost impossible to fix.

I thought this was paranoia until it bit us directly in the butt at FSC North Charleston last year.  Though that laptop was made our driver station in 2018 and it was used then.  I expect we’ll be doing a hub on our new panel.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Zook:

use a USB hub and never unplug it

We built a simple operator console this year with a 1" grid of laser cut holes. To that, we zip tied the USB adapter plus all the cables for strain relief (and “do not unplug and take this controller over to a secret programming lair!”) Handles came from Amazon (the “1” really is 1 pack of 10 handles for $7)
